title:
Mixing and Geometry in the North Atlantic Meridional Overturning
  Circulation
authors: Renzo Bruera, Jezabel Curbelo, Guillermo Garcia-Sanchez, Ana M. Mancho
abstract:
Vertical motions across the ocean are central to processes, like CO$_2$
fixation, heat removal or pollutant transport, which are essential to the
Earth's climate. This work explores 3D conveyor routes {associated with} the
Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC). Our findings show the
geometry of mixing structures in the upper and deep ocean layers by means of
Lagrangian Coherent Structures. This tool identifies among others, zones linked
to vertical transport and characterizes vertical transport time scales. We
focus the study in two regions. The first one is the Flemish Cap region, a zone
of interaction between the major AMOC components, where our analysis identifies
a domain of deep waters that ascend very rapidly to the ocean surface. The
second one is the Irminger Sea, where our analysis confirms the existence of a
downwelling zone, and reveals a previously unreported upwelling connection
between very deep waters and the ocean surface.
